column1: The Three Stigmata of Palmer Eldritch
column7: As crazy as ever, and often tricky to follow the flips in and out of realities, but ultimately very inventive and enjoyable book.

column1: The Long Race to Glory: How the British Came to Rule the Cycling World
column7: Not much more than a timeline through British Cycling history, namechecking loads of people along the way. Not a huge amount of analysis.
column11: https://www.amazon.co.uk/s/ref=nb_sb_ss_c_2_12?url=search-alias%3Dstripbooks&field-keywords=The Long Race to Glory: How the British Came to Rule the Cycling World

column7: Fun. In digestible chunks. I liked the more serious writing more than the amusing throwaway stuff, but that was good too.

column1: The Hyperion Omnibus: Hyperion, The Fall of Hyperion
column7: Epic. Got into the characters, as their stories played out, though did find some if it all a bit impenetrable, but I think that tends to be par for the course with this kind of mammoth Sci-Fi. There was poetry too, which leaves me cold. Not enough to put me off.
column11: https://www.amazon.co.uk/s/ref=nb_sb_ss_c_2_12?url=search-alias%3Dstripbooks&field-keywords=The Hyperion Omnibus: Hyperion, The Fall of Hyperion

column1: The Woman who Went to Bed for a Year
column7: Simply written and direct style makes it easy to read, but with a subtle cutting edge to the satire. Bit of an abrubt ending.
column11: https://www.amazon.co.uk/s/ref=nb_sb_ss_c_2_12?url=search-alias%3Dstripbooks&field-keywords=The Woman who Went to Bed for a Year

column7: I like Jim Moir(Vic Reeves) - the book was likeable, but not as manically funny as the man. Had it lovely absurd moments. Suspect Vol. 2 will be more fun.

Loved the ideas throughout. Great descriptions of the future planet and creative imaginining about future lifeforms. Really enjoyed the language. The plot was nicely dramtic and all came together really enjoyably.

Really enjoyed this. Been such a long time since I'd read a big art book with lots of colour plates. There are tons in this one, all with cracking descriptions and explainations of the process of creating the work and the ideas behind them. The themed structure was really good too. Brilliant value for so much good art.
Rattled along, great central character and enjoyed the direction it went in.

column1: Rowlandson's Drawings for the English Dance of Death

column7: Took a while to get going, but the second half picked up. Suberbly well thought out and explained setting and great how it all came together. Much like 'Hothouse' it struck me as pretty promising film adaption material.
Entertaining and a bit educational too.
Satisfying thriller - quite tricky to follow at times, but as thrillers do, all came together in the end

column1: The Establishment: And how they get away with it
column7: Very well put together explanation of how things run and how depressingly connected and co-opted civic life has become in this country. Even despite the rallying cry for democratic revolution at the end it was all rather dispiriting.  A reaction which kind of emphasises his point. Thank God for the youngsters.
column11: https://www.amazon.co.uk/s/ref=nb_sb_ss_c_2_12?url=search-alias%3Dstripbooks&field-keywords=The Establishment: And how they get away with it

column7: Drugged up soldiers, Shapeshifting lovers, Musical Psychic Animals, Robot sheepdogs, Lightspeed planet brake and Devolving Alien Bears are the things I remember from this collection of short stories - I've surprised myself.

As is often the case - a general feeling of having enjoyed a book without too much specific info. As we're similar ages, the references were fun but the general feel is pretty universal. Liked the style and glad I picked it up after listening to the Adam Buxton podcast about the book.

Very readable and interesting. Very good on how markets can work. The chapter on how China transitioned from a command ecomnomy was fascinating. Made me look anew at markets as systems, that whilst not ideal are probably the best tool for lots of things - but with some pretty big caveats.

Eat Food, Not too Much, Mostly Plants. Summary from the book, but also a very revealing look at the state we're in when it comes to food. As is often the case with 'ideas' books that explain how things are there's quite a bit of depressing stuff, but enough optimism to balance it out.
